NewsLine.NewsLineText: BUSINESS-HIGHLIGHTS:Reuters Business News Highlights 1527 GMT Sept 23

body.p: Germany faces reform gridlock after election

BERLIN - Germany faced the prospect of continued economic stagnation on Monday after Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder won Sunday's election with a reduced majority that narrowed his scope to implement painful reforms.
Schroeder's centre-left government of Social Democrats and Greens got a majority of just nine over the combined opposition parties, down from 21 at the last election.
War fever drives oil price up to 19-month peak
LONDON - War fever drove U.S. oil prices to a new 19-month high on Monday as dealers took fright at the growing threat of a U.S. assault on Iraq.
Benchmark U.S. crude oil jumped 41 cents to $30.25 a barrel by late morning in London, after setting a high of $30.48, its highest level since February last year.
Wal-Mart sees muted Sept sales, sector suffers

CHICAGO - Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and other top U.S. retailers sounded a cautious note on September sales on Monday, sending shares across the sector lower amid concern that the industry managed only modest improvement over last year's Sept. 11-weakened sales.
Wal-Mart, the world's biggest retailer, said it expected September sales at stores open at least a year to come in near the low end of its growth forecast of 4 percent to 6 percent.
Beiersdorf shares fly on P&G bid talk

FRANKFURT - Shares in Beiersdorf AG soared on Monday as investors flocked back to the maker of Nivea skin products on renewed prospects of a takeover battle involving U.S. consumer products giant Procter & Gamble.
U.S.'s O'Neill-Worst of corporate scandals is past
LEXINGTON - U.S. Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill on Monday said the tide of business accounting scandals that shook Wall Street over the summer appears to have ebbed.

"I am confident that the worst of the corporate scandals is behind us - call them what you will, but I can't believe any CEO still standing would be stupid enough to falsely certify their books. Not when jail time is the certain consequence," O'Neill said in prepared remarks to be delivered to the Lexington Chamber of Commerce and students from the University of Kentucky's business school.
US Aug leading indicators down 3rd straight month
WASHINGTON - A key indicator of U.S. economic activity fell for a third straight month in August, signaling a threat of economic slowdown, a private research firm said on Monday.
The Conference Board said the U.S. index of leading economic indicators fell 0.2 percent in August after a revised 0.1 percent drop in July and a 0.2 percent fall in June.
JDS trims first-quarter sales target

OTTAWA - JDS Uniphase Corp. joined the chorus of companies wounded by a steep slowdown in the telecommunications market on Monday, trimming its first-quarter sales guidance amid slack demand for its fibre-optic components.
Italian jobless rate dips to near 10-yr low

ROME - Italian unemployment fell unexpectedly in July, slipping to its lowest level in almost 10 years and providing a rare ray of light for Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi in an otherwise murky economic landscape.

In a quarterly unemployment report released on Monday national statistics agency ISTAT said the seasonally adjusted jobless rate in the euro zone's third-largest economy was 9.0 percent in July versus 9.1 percent in April.
Dole shares rise 25 pct on management buyout offer

CHICAGO - Shares of Dole Food Co., the world's largest producer of fresh fruits, rose more than 25 percent on Monday, a day after the company's chief executive offered to take Dole private with a $1.26 billion cash bid.
U.S. stocks fall; market gauges sink about 2 pct

NEW YORK - Stocks skidded further at mid-morning on Monday, driving major market gauges down about 2 percent, as dim outlooks from companies ranging from telecom gear maker JDS Uniphase Corp. to retailer Wal-Mart Stores Inc. fanned worries over corporate health.

"We had come to a point where earnings revisions had come down in terms of magnitude with every quarter, but now they seem to be accelerating," said Owen Fitzpatrick, head of U.S. equity group at Deutsche Bank Private Banking, which oversees $7 billion.
